bestBHT.bht: God is pleased not only with the sacrifice of praise with our lips, but also with acts of doing good and communicating to those in need. These sacrificial acts of benevolence and sharing are highly valued by God, surpassing mere ritualistic practices. Through these acts, we truly worship and please God, reflecting His nature of goodness and generosity. Our devotion to God is demonstrated not only in our words, but also in our actions of love and service towards others.

Henry Alford: the fruit of the lips is not the only sacrifice: God must be praised not only with the lips, but with the life
of beneficence and communication (of your means to others who are in want)
for with such sacrifices (viz. beneficence and communication) God is well pleased.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: But the sacrifice of praise with the lips is not enough; there must be also doing good and communicating to the needy.
There must be also doing good and communicating to the needy.
with such—and not mere ritualistic sacrifices.
Albert Barnes: To communicate or impart to others; that is, to share with them what we have. The Greek word means having in common with others.
He is pleased with the sacrifices of prayer and of praise; with the offerings of a broken and a contrite heart: but he is especially pleased with the religion which leads us to do good to others.

God is pleased with this: (1) Because it shows in us a right state of heart; (2) Because it accords with his own nature. He does good continually, and he is pleased with all who evince the same spirit.
Marvin Vincent: But to do good and to communicate forget [της δε ευποιιας και κοινωνιας μη επιλανθανεσθε]. Lit. but be not forgetful of doing good and communicating.
Eupoiia beneficence, N. T. o, o LXX, o Class. For koinwnia communication, of alms, etc., see on Luke 5:10; Acts 2:42. See also Romans 14:26; 2 Corinthians 8:4; 2 Corinthians 9:13.
Comp. the verb koinwnein to impart, Romans 12:13; Romans 14:27; Philippians 4:15.
John Calvin: All the acts and duties of love are so many sacrifices.

If we wish to sacrifice to God, we must call on him and acknowledge his goodness by thanksgiving, and further, that we must do good to our brethren; these are the true sacrifices which Christians ought to offer.
When, therefore, love does not prevail among us, we not only rob men of their right, but God himself, who has by a solemn sentence dedicated to himself what he has commanded to be done to men.
Philip Schaff: There must be also the further sacrifice of a beneficent and generous life; for with such sacrifices 'well-doing' and fellowship in love, in service, and in gifts God is well pleased."
A life of cheerful thankfulness, of ceaseless well-doing, of ready participation with others in the gifts God has entrusted to us these are the offerings of the Gospel.
The one great sin-offering of our Lord possessing ceaseless power.
Archibald T. Robertson: To do good, a doing good.
The three great definitions of worship and religious service in the N.T. are all inward and ethical.
Is well pleased with the sacrifices.
John Gill: But to do good and to communicate forget not... alms should be given, or beneficence be exercised to all men in need, even to our enemies, as well as to our friends and relations; and especially to poor saints, and ministers of the Gospel: and this believers should not 'forget'; which shows that it is a duty of importance; and that men are too apt to neglect it, and should be stirred up unto it."
Doing good in this way, when it is done in faith, springs from love, and is directed to the glory of God, is well pleasing to him.
Yet doing good in this way, when it is done in faith, springs from love, and is directed to the glory of God, is well pleasing to him; yea, these sacrifices are preferred by him to legal ones.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse speaks of the importance of not only offering sacrifices of praise with our lips, but also showing our devotion to God through acts of benevolence and communication, particularly in helping those in need. God is pleased when we not only express our thanks and praise, but also share our resources and actively contribute to the well-being of others. These sacrifices of doing good and communicating are highly valued by God, surpassing mere ritualistic practices. It is through these acts of love and service that we truly worship and please God, reflecting His own nature of goodness and generosity.

To please God, we must not only offer praise with our lips, but also generously share our resources and assist those in need. It is through acts of benevolence and communication that we truly worship and express our devotion to Him. These sacrifices of doing good and communicating are highly esteemed by God, surpassing mere ritualistic practices. By engaging in these acts of love and service, we reflect God's own nature of goodness and generosity and demonstrate our true worship.

Our worship of God goes beyond the mere sacrifice of praise with our lips, as He desires that we also show our devotion through acts of kindness and sharing our resources with those in need. These sacrifices of benevolence and communication are highly valued by God, pleasing Him more than ritualistic practices. By engaging in these acts, we demonstrate our true worship and reflect God's own character of goodness and generosity. It is through these acts of love and service that we please Him.

God is pleased not only with the sacrifice of praise with our lips, but also with acts of doing good and communicating to those in need. These sacrificial acts of benevolence and sharing are highly valued by God, surpassing mere ritualistic practices. Through these acts, we truly worship and please God, reflecting His nature of goodness and generosity. Our devotion to God is demonstrated not only in our words, but also in our actions of love and service towards others.

God is pleased not only with the sacrifice of praise with our lips, but also with acts of doing good and communicating to those in need. These sacrificial acts of benevolence and sharing are highly valued by God, surpassing mere ritualistic practices. Through these acts, we truly worship and please God, reflecting His nature of goodness and generosity. Our devotion to God is demonstrated not only in our words but also in our actions of love and service towards others.
